title.value: Jointly-Learned Exit and Inference for a Dynamic Neural Network: JEI-DNN
title.justification: The title captures the main focus of the research work, which is on designing a jointly learned system for dynamic neural networks.
title.quote: Jointly-Learned Exit and Inference for a Dynamic Neural Network: JEI-DNN

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel training procedure for dynamic neural networks called JEI-DNN that jointly optimizes gating mechanisms and intermediate inference modules. This joint optimization aims to address the train-test mismatch issue and improve uncertainty characterization, leading to significant performance improvements in classification tasks.

type.justification: The paper conducts a series of experiments to validate the effectiveness of the proposed JEI-DNN method on various datasets and models, thus making it an empirical study.
type.quote: We use the vision transformers T2T-ViT-7 and T2T-ViT-14 (Yuan et al., 2021) pretrained on the ImageNet dataset (Deng et al., 2009) which we then transfer-learn to the datasets: CIFAR10, CIFAR100, CIFAR100-LT (Krizhevsky, 2009) and SVHN (Netzer et al., 2011).

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on optimizing and improving dynamic neural networks through a novel joint learning technique.
name.quote: The paper focuses on early-exiting dynamic neural networks (EDNN) and proposes a novel learning procedure for the GMs and IMs given a fixed backbone network.

name.justification: One of the key contributions of the paper is improving uncertainty characterization capabilities.
name.quote: The benefits are threefold: 1) we close the training gap between IMs and GMs, which leads to better performance; 2) the architecture produces reliable uncertainty characterization in the form of conformal intervals and well-calibrated predicted probabilities.

name.justification: Optimizing Intermediate Inference Modules (IMs) is a significant part of the proposed method.
name.quote: Our approach involves joint training so it directly avoids train-test mismatch and provides good uncertainty characterization.

name.justification: The paper addresses the training and optimization of Gating Mechanisms (GMs) in dynamic neural networks.
name.quote: The method introduces a new approach for modeling the probability of exiting at a particular inference module.

name.justification: It is the primary model proposed and validated in the paper.
name.quote: We introduce our method named: Jointly-Learned Exit and Inference for a Dynamic Neural Network (JEI-DNN)

is_contributed.justification: The model is a novel contribution proposed by the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce our method named: Jointly-Learned Exit and Inference for a Dynamic Neural Network (JEI-DNN)

is_executed.justification: The model is executed and validated through experiments.
is_executed.quote: We use the vision transformers T2T-ViT-7 and T2T-ViT-14 (Yuan et al., 2021) pretrained on the ImageNet dataset (Deng et al., 2009) which we then transfer-learn to the datasets: CIFAR10, CIFAR100, CIFAR100-LT (Krizhevsky, 2009) and SVHN (Netzer et al., 2011).

is_compared.justification: The JEI-DNN model is empirically compared against other models.
is_compared.quote: We compare our proposal with the following baselines: BoostedNet (Yu et al., 2023) and L2W-DEN (Han et al., 2022b) are state-of-the-art benchmarks with architecture-agnostic training procedures for general-purpose networks.
